questions.question_text: What is a lodestone?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of artificial magnet made from steel.

options.label: B
options.text: A naturally occurring ore of iron oxide (Fe3O4) which attracts iron and aligns north-south.

options.label: C
options.text: A piece of copper that becomes magnetic when current passes through it.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of magnet used in electric bells.

questions.key_concept: Definition and origin of lodestone.

questions.question_text: From which region is the term 'magnet' derived?

options.label: A
options.text: India

options.label: B
options.text: China

options.label: C
options.text: Magnesia in Asia Minor

options.label: D
options.text: Egypt

questions.key_concept: Origin of the word 'magnet'.

questions.question_text: Why are natural magnets not widely used?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too heavy.

options.label: B
options.text: They are found in irregular shapes and are not magnetically strong enough.

options.label: C
options.text: They are electrically conductive, which is dangerous.

options.label: D
options.text: They lose their magnetism in the presence of heat.

questions.key_concept: Limitations of natural magnets.

questions.question_text: Which ancient civilization is mentioned as using lodestone for navigation?

options.label: A
options.text: Romans

options.label: B
options.text: Greeks

options.label: C
options.text: Chinese

options.label: D
options.text: Babylonians

questions.key_concept: Historical application of natural magnets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key difference between a natural magnet and a typical artificial magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Only artificial magnets can have a north and south pole.

options.label: B
options.text: Natural magnets are made from iron oxide, while artificial magnets are made from pure iron.

options.label: C
options.text: Natural magnets are found in irregular shapes and are weak, while artificial magnets are made in convenient shapes with controlled strength.

options.label: D
options.text: Natural magnets are permanent, while artificial magnets are always temporary.

questions.key_concept: Comparison between natural and artificial magnets.

questions.question_text: Why were artificial magnets developed?

options.label: A
options.text: Because natural magnets were too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: Because natural magnets are electrically charged and unsafe.

options.label: C
options.text: To overcome the limitations of natural magnets (irregular shape and weak strength) for practical use.

options.label: D
options.text: Because natural magnets cannot be used in compasses.

questions.key_concept: Reason for the development of artificial magnets.

questions.question_text: What is the law of magnetic poles?

options.label: A
options.text: Like poles attract, unlike poles repel.

options.label: B
options.text: Like poles repel, unlike poles attract.

options.label: C
options.text: North poles attract all other poles.

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic force depends only on distance, not polarity.

questions.key_concept: Fundamental law of attraction and repulsion between magnetic poles.

questions.question_text: When a freely suspended magnet comes to rest, its north pole points towards the geographic ___.

options.label: A
options.text: East

options.label: B
options.text: West

options.label: C
options.text: North

options.label: D
options.text: South

questions.key_concept: Behavior of a freely suspended magnet.

questions.question_text: If the north pole of magnet A attracts the south pole of magnet B, what will happen when the north pole of A is brought near the north pole of B?

options.label: A
options.text: They will attract each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They will repel each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They will have no effect on each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They will first attract, then repel.

questions.key_concept: Application of the law of poles; trap in confusing attraction with repulsion.

questions.question_text: Two identical bars look alike. When the ends labeled 'X' of both bars are brought close, they repel. What can be concluded?

options.label: A
options.text: Both bars are unmagnetized.

options.label: B
options.text: The 'X' ends are like poles.

options.label: C
options.text: The 'X' ends are unlike poles.

options.label: D
options.text: One bar is made of iron, the other of steel.

questions.key_concept: Using repulsion to identify magnetic poles.

questions.question_text: How does the force between two magnetic poles differ from the force between two electric charges?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic poles always attract; electric charges can attract or repel.

options.label: B
options.text: Both follow the same rule: like repel, unlike attract.

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic poles can be isolated like electric charges.

options.label: D
options.text: Electric force depends on material, magnetic force does not.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of fundamental force laws (analogy).

questions.question_text: Why is repulsion considered a sure test for magnetism?

options.label: A
options.text: Because only magnets can produce a force strong enough to repel.

options.label: B
options.text: Because attraction can occur between a magnet and an unmagnetized magnetic material, but repulsion occurs only between two like poles of magnets.

options.label: C
options.text: Because unmagnetized materials always repel each other.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth's magnetic field causes repulsion between magnets.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the repulsion test for a magnet.

questions.question_text: What is induced magnetism?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent magnetism acquired by heating a magnetic material.

options.label: B
options.text: Temporary magnetism acquired by a magnetic material when kept near a magnet.

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetism produced by passing electric current through a coil.

options.label: D
options.text: The natural magnetism of lodestone.

questions.key_concept: Definition of induced magnetism.

questions.question_text: The process by which a magnetic material temporarily acquires magnetism in the presence of a magnet is called ___.

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic attraction

options.label: B
options.text: Magnetic induction

options.label: C
options.text: Polarization

options.label: D
options.text: Electromagnetism

questions.key_concept: Terminology for the process of inducing magnetism.

questions.question_text: A north pole of a magnet is brought near end A of an unmagnetized iron bar. What polarity is induced at end A?

options.label: A
options.text: North

options.label: B
options.text: South

options.label: C
options.text: No polarity is induced.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the material of the bar.

questions.key_concept: Rule of induction: opposite polarity on the near end. Trap is choosing the same pole.

questions.question_text: Why do iron filings cling to a magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to gravitational force.

options.label: B
options.text: Each filing becomes a temporary magnet by induction and is then attracted.

options.label: C
options.text: Due to static electricity generated by the magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are naturally magnetic.

questions.key_concept: Application of magnetic induction to explain attraction of iron filings.

questions.question_text: How does induced magnetism in soft iron differ from that in steel when the inducing magnet is removed?

options.label: A
options.text: Both lose magnetism instantly.

options.label: B
options.text: Soft iron loses magnetism quickly; steel retains it longer.

options.label: C
options.text: Steel loses magnetism quickly; soft iron retains it.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither gets magnetized by induction.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of magnetic retention (retentivity) post-induction.

questions.question_text: Why does the statement 'induction precedes attraction' hold true?

options.label: A
options.text: Because a magnetic field must first be created before any force can act.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the unmagnetized piece first becomes a magnet (with opposite pole induced near the magnet) and then attraction occurs between unlike poles.

options.label: C
options.text: Because attraction is a slower process than induction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth's magnetic field induces first, then the magnet attracts.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the sequence: induction then attraction.

questions.question_text: What is a magnetic field?

options.label: A
options.text: The force between two magnets.

options.label: B
options.text: The space around a magnet where its influence can be detected by a magnetic needle.

options.label: C
options.text: The lines drawn on paper around a magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: The region inside a magnet.

questions.key_concept: Definition of magnetic field.

questions.question_text: How is the direction of the magnetic field at a point defined?

options.label: A
options.text: Direction of force on a stationary charge.

options.label: B
options.text: Direction in which the north pole of a compass needle points when placed at that point.

options.label: C
options.text: Direction from south to north pole inside the magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: Direction of gravitational force.

questions.key_concept: Definition of magnetic field direction.

questions.question_text: Magnetic field is a ___ quantity.

options.label: A
options.text: Scalar

options.label: B
options.text: Vector

options.label: C
options.text: Tensor

options.label: D
options.text: Dimensionless

questions.key_concept: Nature of magnetic field (vector). Trap is confusing it with scalar.

questions.question_text: If a compass needle does not deflect from geographic north-south at a point, what does it indicate about the magnetic field at that point?

options.label: A
options.text: The magnetic field is very strong.

options.label: B
options.text: The magnetic field is zero or aligned with Earth's field.

options.label: C
options.text: The compass is broken.

options.label: D
options.text: The point is exactly at the magnetic pole.

questions.key_concept: Interpreting compass behavior to infer magnetic field.

questions.question_text: How does the magnetic field strength typically vary with distance from a bar magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases with distance.

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases with distance.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains constant.

options.label: D
options.text: It first increases, then decreases.

questions.key_concept: Relationship between field strength and distance.

questions.question_text: Why is a magnetic field considered a vector field?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has both magnitude and a specified direction at every point.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can be seen as lines.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it affects only magnetic materials.

options.label: D
options.text: Because its strength is measured in tesla.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for the vector nature of magnetic field.

concepts.concept_name: Magnetic Field Lines and their Properties

questions.question_text: What are magnetic field lines?

options.label: A
options.text: Straight lines connecting north and south poles.

options.label: B
options.text: Curved lines along which an iron filing aligns itself or a compass needle points.

options.label: C
options.text: Lines of force that exist only inside a magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: Grid lines used to map geographic locations.

questions.key_concept: Definition of magnetic field lines.

questions.question_text: Outside a magnet, the direction of magnetic field lines is from ___ pole to ___ pole.

options.label: A
options.text: south, north

options.label: B
options.text: north, south

options.label: C
options.text: east, west

options.label: D
options.text: west, east

questions.key_concept: Standard direction of magnetic field lines outside a magnet.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a property of magnetic field lines?

options.label: A
options.text: They are closed continuous curves.

options.label: B
options.text: They can intersect each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The tangent at a point gives the field direction.

options.label: D
options.text: They are crowded where the field is strong.

questions.key_concept: Properties of field lines. Trap is identifying the false statement.

questions.question_text: What does a pattern of parallel, equidistant magnetic field lines represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The field of a bar magnet.

options.label: B
options.text: A non-uniform magnetic field.

options.label: C
options.text: A uniform magnetic field.

options.label: D
options.text: A neutral point.

questions.key_concept: Interpreting field line patterns to identify uniform field.

questions.question_text: How do magnetic field lines behave near the poles compared to near the middle of a bar magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more crowded near the poles, indicating stronger field.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more crowded near the middle, indicating stronger field.

options.label: C
options.text: They are equally spaced everywhere.

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear near the poles.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of field line density and field strength.

questions.question_text: Why can two magnetic field lines never intersect?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they would cancel each other out.

options.label: B
options.text: Because at the point of intersection, a compass needle would point in two different directions, which is impossible.

options.label: C
options.text: Because magnetic fields are always parallel.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are lines of different magnets.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the non-intersection property of field lines.

concepts.concept_name: Earth's Magnetic Field - Evidence and Nature

questions.question_text: What is the primary evidence that Earth has a magnetic field?

options.label: A
options.text: Volcanic eruptions.

options.label: B
options.text: A freely suspended magnetic needle rests in geographic north-south direction.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of iron in Earth's core.

options.label: D
options.text: Solar flares.

questions.key_concept: Key evidence for Earth's magnetic field.

questions.question_text: Earth's magnetic south pole is located near the geographic ___.

options.label: A
options.text: South pole

options.label: B
options.text: North pole

options.label: C
options.text: Equator

options.label: D
options.text: Prime Meridian

questions.key_concept: Location of Earth's magnetic poles relative to geographic poles.

questions.question_text: An iron rod buried along the north-south direction becomes a weak magnet. This happens due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Lightning strikes.

options.label: B
options.text: Induction by the Earth's magnetic field.

options.label: C
options.text: Heating from the Earth's interior.

options.label: D
options.text: Chemical reaction with soil.

questions.key_concept: Evidence of Earth's magnetism through induction. Trap is choosing a non-magnetic cause.

questions.question_text: Where on Earth would a magnetic needle become vertical?

options.label: A
options.text: At the magnetic equator.

options.label: B
options.text: At the geographic equator.

options.label: C
options.text: At the magnetic poles.

options.label: D
options.text: At any place with high altitude.

questions.key_concept: Application of Earth's field direction at different locations.

questions.question_text: How does the direction of Earth's magnetic field lines compare to that of a bar magnet placed along the north-south direction?

options.label: A
options.text: Earth's field lines go from geographic south to north (like from S to N outside a magnet).

options.label: B
options.text: Earth's field lines go from geographic north to south.

options.label: C
options.text: They are identical to the field lines of a bar magnet with N pointing geographic north.

options.label: D
options.text: Earth has no defined field line direction.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of Earth's field direction with a standard bar magnet.

questions.question_text: Why does a freely suspended magnet point north-south?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to gravitational pull of the poles.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Earth's magnetic south pole (near geographic north) attracts the magnet's north pole.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the rotation of the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the magnet aligns with the Sun's position.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for the north-south alignment of a compass.

concepts.concept_name: Uniform Magnetic Field of Earth and Plotting

questions.question_text: In a limited space, Earth's magnetic field lines are ___.

options.label: A
options.text: curved and converging

options.label: B
options.text: parallel and equidistant

options.label: C
options.text: intersecting

options.label: D
options.text: circular

questions.key_concept: Nature of Earth's magnetic field in a limited space (uniform).

questions.question_text: What instrument is used to plot the magnetic field lines of Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Barometer

options.label: B
options.text: Thermometer

options.label: C
options.text: Compass needle

options.label: D
options.text: Voltmeter

questions.key_concept: Tool for plotting Earth's magnetic field lines.

questions.question_text: When plotting Earth's uniform magnetic field lines, the direction indicated by the arrow on the field line is from:

options.label: A
options.text: Geographic north to geographic south.

options.label: B
options.text: Geographic south to geographic north.

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic north to magnetic south.

options.label: D
options.text: East to west.

questions.key_concept: Direction of Earth's magnetic field lines. Trap is confusing geographic with magnetic poles.

questions.question_text: In the experiment to plot Earth's magnetic field, why are dots marked at both ends of the compass needle?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the needle's length.

options.label: B
options.text: To get a straight line connecting the dots, representing the field line direction.

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the magnetic field strength.

options.label: D
options.text: To check if the needle is magnetized.

questions.key_concept: Methodology of plotting field lines with a compass.

questions.question_text: How does the pattern of Earth's magnetic field lines in a limited space differ from the pattern around a bar magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Earth's lines are parallel and equidistant; bar magnet's lines are curved and non-uniform.

options.label: B
options.text: Earth's lines are circular; bar magnet's lines are straight.

options.label: C
options.text: Earth's lines intersect; bar magnet's lines do not.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; both patterns are identical.

questions.key_concept: Comparison between uniform (Earth) and non-uniform (bar magnet) field patterns.

questions.question_text: Why is Earth's magnetic field considered uniform in a limited space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth is perfectly spherical.

options.label: B
options.text: Because at a small scale, the field lines appear parallel and equidistant due to the large distance from Earth's magnetic poles.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the field strength is zero everywhere.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the compass needle always points north.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for the uniformity of Earth's magnetic field locally.

concepts.concept_name: Non-uniform Magnetic Field of a Bar Magnet

questions.question_text: What characterizes a non-uniform magnetic field?

options.label: A
options.text: Parallel and equidistant field lines.

options.label: B
options.text: Field lines that are curved and not equally spaced.

options.label: C
options.text: Field lines that intersect each other.

options.label: D
options.text: Field lines that are only straight.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a non-uniform magnetic field.

questions.question_text: The magnetic field lines around a bar magnet are ___.

options.label: A
options.text: uniform

options.label: B
options.text: non-uniform

options.label: C
options.text: absent

options.label: D
options.text: always circular

questions.key_concept: Nature of magnetic field around a bar magnet.

questions.question_text: Where is the magnetic field strongest around a bar magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: At the exact center.

options.label: B
options.text: Midway between the poles.

options.label: C
options.text: Near the poles.

options.label: D
options.text: At a large distance from the magnet.

questions.key_concept: Location of maximum field strength. Trap is choosing the center.

questions.question_text: What does the crowding of magnetic field lines indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Weaker magnetic field.

options.label: B
options.text: Stronger magnetic field.

options.label: C
options.text: Uniform magnetic field.

options.label: D
options.text: Zero magnetic field.

questions.key_concept: Interpreting field line density.

questions.question_text: How does the magnetic field pattern for two unlike poles facing each other differ from that of two like poles facing each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Unlike poles: field lines connect the poles; Like poles: field lines avoid the region between poles.

options.label: B
options.text: Unlike poles: field lines are parallel; Like poles: field lines are circular.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no difference.

options.label: D
options.text: Unlike poles: field lines are straight; Like poles: field lines are curved.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of field patterns for different pole configurations.

questions.question_text: Why are magnetic field lines closer near the poles of a bar magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the magnetic force is weaker there.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the magnetic field is stronger near the poles, and field line density represents field strength.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the lines start and end at the poles.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the shape of the magnet.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for field line density variation.

questions.question_text: What is a neutral point in magnetism?

options.label: A
options.text: A point where the magnetic field is maximum.

options.label: B
options.text: A point where the resultant magnetic field is zero.

options.label: C
options.text: The center of a magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: A point on the magnetic equator.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a neutral point.

questions.question_text: At a neutral point, a compass needle ___.

options.label: A
options.text: points strongly north

options.label: B
options.text: points strongly south

options.label: C
options.text: is unaffected and can rest in any direction

options.label: D
options.text: vibrates rapidly

questions.key_concept: Behavior of a compass at a neutral point.

questions.question_text: Neutral points occur where:

options.label: A
options.text: Only the Earth's magnetic field is present.

options.label: B
options.text: The magnetic field of a magnet and Earth's horizontal field cancel each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Two magnets have equal and same direction fields.

options.label: D
options.text: The magnetic field is too weak to detect.

questions.key_concept: Condition for neutral point formation. Trap is choosing a scenario without cancellation.

questions.question_text: When a bar magnet is placed with its north pole facing geographic north, where are the neutral points located?

options.label: A
options.text: North and south of the magnet.

options.label: B
options.text: East and west of the magnet.

options.label: C
options.text: Above and below the magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: At the poles of the magnet.

questions.key_concept: Location of neutral points for a specific magnet orientation.

questions.question_text: How do the positions of neutral points differ when a magnet's north pole faces geographic north versus when its south pole faces geographic north?

options.label: A
options.text: N facing N: east-west; S facing N: north-south.

options.label: B
options.text: N facing N: north-south; S facing N: east-west.

options.label: C
options.text: Both orientations give neutral points in the same position.

options.label: D
options.text: Neutral points exist only when N faces N.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of neutral point positions based on magnet orientation.

questions.question_text: Why is the resultant magnetic field zero at a neutral point?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there are no magnetic materials nearby.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the magnetic field due to the magnet and the horizontal component of Earth's field are equal and opposite.

options.label: C
options.text: Because gravity cancels the magnetic force.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the point is too far from all magnets.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for zero net field at neutral point.

concepts.concept_name: Plotting Field Lines with Neutral Points (Magnet in Meridian)

questions.question_text: What is meant by placing a magnet in the 'magnetic meridian'?

options.label: A
options.text: Placing it along the geographic east-west direction.

options.label: B
options.text: Placing it along the direction in which a freely suspended magnet rests (north-south).

options.label: C
options.text: Placing it vertically.

options.label: D
options.text: Placing it at the magnetic equator.

questions.key_concept: Definition of magnetic meridian in context of experiments.

questions.question_text: In the plotted field pattern of a bar magnet (N facing geographic N), field lines are curved near the magnet and straight at a distance because:

options.label: A
options.text: The paper is too small.

options.label: B
options.text: Near the magnet, its field dominates; far away, Earth's uniform field dominates.

options.label: C
options.text: The compass needle is unreliable near the magnet.

options.label: D
options.text: The field lines always start straight and then curve.

questions.key_concept: Interpretation of combined field line pattern.

questions.question_text: When plotting the field of a bar magnet with its north pole facing geographic north, the neutral points lie on a line that is ___ to the magnetic axis.

options.label: A
options.text: parallel

options.label: B
options.text: perpendicular

options.label: C
options.text: at 45 degrees

options.label: D
options.text: coincident

questions.key_concept: Geometric relation of neutral points to magnet axis. Trap is choosing parallel.

questions.question_text: In the experiment, if you start plotting a field line from a point very close to the north pole of the magnet, where will the line end?

options.label: A
options.text: At the south pole of the same magnet.

options.label: B
options.text: At the geographic north pole.

options.label: C
options.text: It will go off to infinity in a straight line.

options.label: D
options.text: At the neutral point.

questions.key_concept: Path of a field line starting near a pole.

questions.question_text: Compare the field line pattern when a magnet's N faces N vs. when its S faces N. What is a key visual difference regarding neutral points?

options.label: A
options.text: N faces N: neutral points are inside the magnet; S faces N: neutral points are outside.

options.label: B
options.text: N faces N: neutral points are on the equatorial line (E-W); S faces N: neutral points are on the axial line (N-S).

options.label: C
options.text: Both patterns have neutral points at the same locations.

options.label: D
options.text: Only one orientation produces neutral points.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of field plots showing different neutral point alignments.

questions.question_text: Why does the plotted field line pattern for a magnet in the meridian show a combination of curved and straight lines?

options.label: A
options.text: It's an error in the plotting technique.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the vector superposition of the non-uniform field of the magnet and the uniform field of the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: The paper is not large enough to show all curved lines.

options.label: D
options.text: The compass needle is only sensitive near the magnet.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the combined field line pattern.

questions.question_text: What is an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: A permanent magnet made from steel.

options.label: B
options.text: A temporary magnet formed when electric current flows through a coil wound on a soft iron core.

options.label: C
options.text: A magnet found in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: A magnet that works only with alternating current.

questions.key_concept: Definition of an electromagnet.

questions.question_text: Which material is used for the core of an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Steel

options.label: B
options.text: Copper

options.label: C
options.text: Soft iron

options.label: D
options.text: Aluminium

questions.key_concept: Core material for electromagnets.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet loses its magnetism when the current is switched off because:

options.label: A
options.text: The coil gets heated.

options.label: B
options.text: Soft iron has low retentivity.

options.label: C
options.text: The magnetic field is stored in the battery.

options.label: D
options.text: The coil's insulation breaks down.

questions.key_concept: Reason for temporary magnetism. Trap is choosing an unrelated cause.

questions.question_text: To determine the polarity of an I-shaped electromagnet, one can use:

options.label: A
options.text: The right-hand grip rule.

options.label: B
options.text: The left-hand rule.

options.label: C
options.text: The law of gravitation.

options.label: D
options.text: By measuring its weight.

questions.key_concept: Determining polarity of an electromagnet.

questions.question_text: How does the magnetism of an I-shaped electromagnet differ from that of a U-shaped (horse-shoe) electromagnet with the same core material and current?

options.label: A
options.text: The U-shaped magnet produces a stronger field in the gap between its poles.

options.label: B
options.text: The I-shaped magnet is always permanent.

options.label: C
options.text: The U-shaped magnet works only with AC.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference in magnetic field strength.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of field strength based on electromagnet shape.

questions.question_text: Why is soft iron preferred over steel for the core of an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Because soft iron is cheaper.

options.label: B
options.text: Because soft iron has high retentivity, making the magnet permanent.

options.label: C
options.text: Because soft iron has high permeability and low retentivity, allowing quick magnetization and demagnetization.

options.label: D
options.text: Because steel cannot be wound with a coil.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for choice of core material based on magnetic properties.

concepts.concept_name: Factors Affecting Strength of an Electromagnet

questions.question_text: The strength of an electromagnet can be increased by:

options.label: A
options.text: Using a steel core.

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of turns in the coil.

options.label: C
options.text: Using thicker insulation on the wire.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the current.

questions.key_concept: One factor affecting electromagnet strength.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will NOT increase the strength of an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the current.

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of turns.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a core with lower permeability.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a U-shaped core instead of an I-shaped one.

questions.key_concept: Identifying a factor that does not increase strength.

questions.question_text: If you double the current in an electromagnet's coil, its magnetic field strength typically:

options.label: A
options.text: Halves.

options.label: B
options.text: Remains the same.

options.label: C
options.text: Doubles.

options.label: D
options.text: Becomes zero.

questions.key_concept: Direct proportionality between current and field strength (within limits). Trap is inverse relationship.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet needs to lift heavier scrap iron. What practical change can be made?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a longer connecting wire.

options.label: B
options.text: Increase the voltage of the power supply to increase current.

options.label: C
options.text: Paint the core a different color.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a smaller battery.

questions.key_concept: Practical application of increasing electromagnet strength.

questions.question_text: How does increasing the number of turns differ from increasing the current in terms of their effect on the electromagnet's heat production?

options.label: A
options.text: Both increase heat production equally.

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing turns increases resistance and may increase heat for the same voltage; increasing current directly increases heat (IR).

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing turns decreases heat; increasing current increases heat.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither affects heat production.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of side effects when strengthening an electromagnet.

questions.question_text: Why does increasing the number of turns in the coil strengthen the electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the resistance, reducing heat loss.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the coil more compact.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the total magnetic effect (ampere-turns) for a given current.

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases the need for a core.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the 'number of turns' factor.

questions.question_text: What is a permanent magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: A magnet that lasts for only a few minutes.

options.label: B
options.text: A magnet that retains its magnetism for a long time after being magnetized.

options.label: C
options.text: A magnet that works only when electricity is supplied.

options.label: D
options.text: A magnet made from soft iron.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a permanent magnet.

questions.question_text: Which material is typically used to make a permanent magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Soft iron

options.label: B
options.text: Steel

options.label: C
options.text: Copper

options.label: D
options.text: Aluminium

questions.key_concept: Material for permanent magnets.

questions.question_text: A major difference between an electromagnet and a permanent magnet is:

options.label: A
options.text: Only permanent magnets have poles.

options.label: B
options.text: The strength of an electromagnet can be easily varied, while that of a permanent magnet cannot.

options.label: C
options.text: Permanent magnets are always weaker.

options.label: D
options.text: Electromagnets are made of steel.

questions.key_concept: Key difference. Trap is choosing a false or minor difference.

questions.question_text: Where would you most likely use a permanent magnet rather than an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: In a scrap yard crane to lift iron.

options.label: B
options.text: In the core of a transformer.

options.label: C
options.text: In a magnetic compass.

options.label: D
options.text: In an electric bell.

questions.key_concept: Application suited for permanent magnet's constant field.

questions.question_text: Which property of the core material primarily dictates whether the resulting magnet is temporary (electromagnet) or permanent?

options.label: A
options.text: Color

options.label: B
options.text: Density

options.label: C
options.text: Retentivity (or coercivity)

options.label: D
options.text: Electrical conductivity

questions.key_concept: Material property governing permanence of magnetism.

questions.question_text: Why is steel not suitable for the core of a typical electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not magnetic.

options.label: B
options.text: It has high retentivity, so it would not lose magnetism quickly when current stops, defeating the purpose of a switchable magnet.

options.label: C
options.text: It is too expensive.

options.label: D
options.text: It has low permeability, so it wouldn't get strongly magnetized.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning against using steel for electromagnet core.

questions.question_text: Which is a major advantage of an electromagnet over a permanent magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It is always lighter.

options.label: B
options.text: Its strength can be easily controlled.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not require any power source.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always cheaper.

questions.key_concept: Key advantage of electromagnets.

questions.question_text: Electromagnets are used in:

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic compasses.

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent magnet speakers.

options.label: C
options.text: Electric bells and cranes.

options.label: D
options.text: Bar magnets for school experiments.

questions.key_concept: Common uses of electromagnets.

questions.question_text: Why are electromagnets preferred in cranes for lifting iron scrap?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are naturally stronger than any permanent magnet.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can be switched on to lift and switched off to drop the load easily.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they work without electricity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not affected by heat.

questions.key_concept: Advantage for material handling. Trap is choosing an incorrect or exaggerated reason.

questions.question_text: In which device is the 'make and break' mechanism of an electromagnet's circuit essential for its function?

options.label: A
options.text: Electric heater

options.label: B
options.text: Electric bell

options.label: C
options.text: Electric lamp

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic compass

questions.key_concept: Specific application using the intermittent operation of an electromagnet.

questions.question_text: Compared to a permanent magnet, what operational flexibility do electromagnets offer? (Choose the most comprehensive)

options.label: A
options.text: Only strength can be changed.

options.label: B
options.text: Strength can be changed, polarity can be reversed, and they can be turned on/off.

options.label: C
options.text: Only polarity can be reversed.

options.label: D
options.text: They can change shape.

questions.key_concept: Combined advantages/flexibilities of electromagnets.

questions.question_text: Why is the ability to reverse polarity an advantage of an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the magnet to attract both north and south poles.

options.label: B
options.text: It is useful in devices like DC motors where the direction of force needs to be reversed.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the magnet stronger.

options.label: D
options.text: It prevents the core from heating up.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the advantage of polarity reversal.

questions.question_text: What is the main function of the electromagnet in an electric bell?

options.label: A
options.text: To power the entire circuit.

options.label: B
options.text: To attract the soft iron armature when current flows.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce sound directly.

options.label: D
options.text: To hold the bell in place.

questions.key_concept: Role of electromagnet in electric bell.

questions.question_text: In an electric bell, what breaks the circuit when the armature is attracted?

options.label: A
options.text: The gong

options.label: B
options.text: The hammer

options.label: C
options.text: The contact screw (adjusting screw)

options.label: D
options.text: The battery

questions.key_concept: Component responsible for the 'break' in make-and-break.

questions.question_text: What happens immediately after the circuit of an electric bell is broken?

options.label: A
options.text: The electromagnet becomes stronger.

options.label: B
options.text: The armature springs back, remaking the contact.

options.label: C
options.text: The bell stops ringing permanently.

options.label: D
options.text: The battery discharges instantly.

questions.key_concept: Sequence after break. Trap is thinking the process stops.

questions.question_text: Why is soft iron used for the armature of an electric bell?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a good conductor of electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be easily magnetized and demagnetized rapidly.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the cheapest metal.

options.label: D
options.text: It produces sound when hit.

questions.key_concept: Suitability of soft iron for the armature.

questions.question_text: How would the bell's operation be affected if a permanent magnet were used instead of an electromagnet?

options.label: A
options.text: It would ring continuously without stopping.

options.label: B
options.text: The armature would be permanently attracted, and the make-and-break action would not occur.

options.label: C
options.text: It would ring louder.

options.label: D
options.text: It would not work at all because no circuit would be formed.

questions.key_concept: Criticality of the electromagnet's temporary magnetism for the bell's working.

questions.question_text: Why does an electric bell work with both DC and AC supply?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bell has a built-in rectifier.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the attraction of the armature depends only on the presence of a magnetic field, not its steady polarity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because AC generates more heat, making it work better.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the gong vibrates at AC frequency.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning for compatibility with AC.

concepts.concept_name: Testing and Identifying Magnetic Materials and Poles

questions.question_text: Without any other magnet, how can you identify which of two identical bars is magnetized?

options.label: A
options.text: By weighing them.

options.label: B
options.text: By suspending each freely; the one that rests in N-S direction is magnetized.

options.label: C
options.text: By touching them to paper.

options.label: D
options.text: By heating them.

questions.key_concept: Test to identify a magnet.

questions.question_text: To test if a rod is made of iron or copper, you can:

options.label: A
options.text: Measure its length.

options.label: B
options.text: Bring a magnet near it; iron will be attracted, copper will not.

options.label: C
options.text: Bring a magnet near it; iron will get magnetized by induction and attract filings, copper will not.

options.label: D
options.text: Check its color.

questions.key_concept: Test to distinguish magnetic from non-magnetic material.

questions.question_text: Why is repulsion, not attraction, a sure test for magnetism?

options.label: A
options.text: Because attraction is weaker.

options.label: B
options.text: Because an unmagnetized magnetic material can be attracted, but only a magnet can repel.

options.label: C
options.text: Because repulsion is easier to observe.

options.label: D
options.text: Because all materials repel magnets.

questions.key_concept: The 'sure test' principle. Trap is misstating the reason.

questions.question_text: Given a magnetized bar and a compass, how do you find the north pole of the bar?

options.label: A
options.text: Bring the bar near the compass's north pole; the end that repels is the north pole of the bar.

options.label: B
options.text: Bring the bar near the compass's south pole; the end that attracts is the north pole.

options.label: C
options.text: Heat the bar; the end that gets hot is the north pole.

options.label: D
options.text: Dip it in water; the end that floats points north.

questions.key_concept: Practical method to identify pole using a compass.

questions.question_text: Compare the behavior of a soft iron bar and a magnet when suspended freely.

options.label: A
options.text: Both will align north-south.

options.label: B
options.text: The magnet aligns north-south; the soft iron bar may come to rest in any direction.

options.label: C
options.text: The soft iron bar aligns north-south; the magnet aligns east-west.

options.label: D
options.text: Both will come to rest in any direction.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of behavior when suspended.

questions.question_text: A bar is brought near the north pole of a known magnet. If it is repelled, why can you conclusively say the bar is a magnet with its north pole facing the known magnet?

options.label: A
options.text: Because only a north pole can cause repulsion.

options.label: B
options.text: Because repulsion occurs only between like poles, so the end facing the known magnet's north must also be a north pole.

options.label: C
options.text: Because unmagnetized iron always repels north poles.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth's field causes the repulsion.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning based on the law of poles and the sure test.
